job_title: Senior House Officer in Chelsea, England
pros: As hospital is roughly 50% private and 50% NHS, has some great perks vs traditional NHS hospitals, for example subsidised meals and safer patient to doctor ratios. Nice location (Chelsea site). very pleasant and competent nursing teams. Excellent additional staff benefits available to staff directly employed by trust (study grants, cycle to work schemes, other budgets etc).
cons: Presently poor IT system, however this is being addressed in March 2023. Pan - London rates for locum SHOs, however better rates for OOH work.

review_title: Great staff but more support needed for staff.

review_title: Great place to start with the Administrator role

review_title: Legendary oncology hospital sufffering from cancer itself.
job_title: Staff Nurse (RN) in Clapham Junction, England
pros: Great area, great people, superb service, plenty of career growth.
cons:
Overworked. The ward that I used to be in was accepting everything and every case from the hospital. Patient turnover was so high and so fast the overload was too much for the staff.

Bullying. Very evident mainly because of overload related to the shortage of staff that the staff are taking it against each other. 

Toxic environment. Not healthy workplace even for other disciplines of care. It seems the culture allows senior staff to be toxic to junior staff that generates a cycle of aggression. Doctors to nurses, nurses to doctors, no one is safe.

pros: Given the constraints on nhs organisations the Marsden is an innovative investor in its employees.

review_title: Children nurse: development opportunists to only a select few

review_title: Lovely place if you are one of their favourites
job_title: Senior I Therapeutic Radiographer in London, England
pros: Other staff are generally lovely.
cons: If your face doesn’t fit or you are in any way not mainstream and their idea of ‘normal’ you will be overlooked and only grudgingly allowed to progress. If you are one of their chosen favourites (cookie cutter, corporate poster child) you will have every possible opportunity thrown at your feet.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Assistant in Sutton, London, England
pros:
The Marsden has an excellent continuing professional development programme, with lectures once a month. It seemed to be mostly for biomedical scientists (and I am not a biomedical scientist by training), however my manager encouraged me to go along too in order to continue learning. In addition to this, when lockdown restrictions started easing, I felt that my manager was fighting our corner to ensure our safety when the "higher-ups" were pressuring us into all coming back full time. This was important as the office and lab spaces we had were very small, so it would have been impossible to be socially distant from each other.
I received ample encouragement to progress my training and career, and felt constantly supported by my team. 
There is also a free shuttle bus for staff members from Sutton train station to the hospital and back.
cons:
Parking can be a nightmare if you're even 2 minutes later than usual. 
Some members of staff weren't very easy to get along with on my team, however I have yet to work in a place where everyone is perfect!

job_title: Senior Admission Officer in Carshalton, England
pros:
Friendly atmosphere 
Lots of opportunities 
Good family work balance
cons: Management can be annoying and don't care about staff

job_title: Healthcare Assistant in London, England

review_title: Great place to work in provided you like steady and not exciting envionment
job_title: Officer In Estate Department in London, England
pros:
great colleagues
great work/life balance as hardly ever asked to do any overtimes
it's NHS so relatively low stress environment
depending on the senior one can get very good training opportunities
cons:
work can get pretty boring and repetitive and there is very little scope for personal growth as higher positions are taken by people who have been in NHS for eternity
very bad HR policies, most of the staff were (it could have changed by now) agency contact hence not eligible for leave, maternity etc pay
if you like dynamic environment - not a good place to be in as one gets bored to death

review_title: Inspiring individuals who make a difference everyday
job_title: Head of Marketing in London, England
pros: I n my time at The Royal Marsden I had the privilege to work with so many amazing people. Overall great work ethic, people who really care, try their best and make a positive difference every day.
cons: Some departments work in silos and as a result deliver a fragmented experience. HR needs major improvement in terms of technology and support around processes and tools.  Some departments need to collaborate more strongly with other departments to deliver a more cohesive experience to various audiences.

review_title: Senior Biological Specimen Coordinator, G.I & Lymphoma Unit
job_title: Specimen Collector in Sutton, London, England
pros: Great to have experience of working at the trust on your C.V if looking to advance in the field
cons: Poorly managed teams. Favouritism. No consideration to work life balance. Parking issues at both sites. Hard workers not appreciated. People allowed to get away with doing minimum work. No sense of professionalism in G.I Unit. Very slow HR process once offered a job within the trust.

review_title: Excellent company with friendly staff and a fantastic mission
job_title: Medical Laboratory Assistant in Belmont, England
pros: World class healthcare and partnered with a world leading cancer research institution (the Institute for Cancer Research(ICR))). It's said that there is a "type" of staff member at the Royal Marsden and you can definitely see it. Compared to staff such as nurses, porters and lab staff at other hospitals, the level of compassion and friendliness here is hard to beat but you couldn't accept anything less when you are responsible for such vulnerable people as the Marsden is
cons: NHS doesn't pay overly well. The on site bar and facilities like swimming pool are unavailable even pre covid

job_title: Manager in London, England
pros: Some real down to earth, honest frontline staff. The doctors and nurses genuinly strive to do their best for their patients.
cons: Marketing/Comms - honest and hardworking team. But management was cliquey, sometimes lacked professionalism (openly criticising previous members of staff; not particularly classy) and slightly stuck in old ways of working. Charity leadership was particularly toxic;  not encouraging, collegiate or motivational  — the atmosphere was heightened and angsty.

job_title: CBU Manager in London, England
pros: The ethos of the organisation and the people in it is incredible. Everyone puts in blood sweat and tears to change the lives of patients- and that makes you work harder. And everyday, someone reminds you of why it's so worth it.
cons:
My role was very stressful because we, like many hospitals, were under resourced.  Every decision had the potential to have impact on patient care and future care delivery so put us under a lot of pressure. 
And Space! They need more theatre capacity and beds!

review_title: Snobby organisation that sees other cancer hospitals and charities as threat
job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
Great pay
Good pension
Talented medical professionals, well known organisation
cons:
When you work there you quickly learn that it's "the Marsden way or no way"
Mistakes are not accepted, you're made to feel stupid and there's no safe working environment where others support you. It's very much a fight-your-own-corner organisation

review_title: Excellent company, management could do with some work.
